comments.commentBody: You're referring to the Malabar Paratha, which is a Keralite specialty. I haven't found it in NYC yet, but you should try out the South Indian restaurants on Lexington Ave in Murray Hill. Saravana Bhavan or Anjappar, though I can't find it on their menus online. If you ever visit the SF/San Jose Bay Area, CA, you'll find it in Spice Hut in Fremont or Sunnyvale.

After 236 years of representative democracy, I'm not sure why anyone would sue about it now. Also, states-rights Republicans would be the last group to sue over a "hodge-podge" of different methods in different states. It'd be like suing the cornerstone of their beliefs. Additionally: who would have standing to file that suit?

JG, You're right.  Unfortunately, Clarke and others became scapegoats.  Womack was unduly shooed (booed?) out of town.  In hindsight, the period should have been known as the Lee McPhailure era.  If I remember correctly, the book Dynasty also Topping and Webb knew they would be selling and stopped investing in the team's farm system.  Supposedly, they could have had Yaz.

"There are 126 delegates,...who are complete free agents."

"A few states do bind their super delegates to the winner of the primary or caucus, but most do not."

I imagine the second sentence above explains the discrepancy you're referring to.
Nate headlined the column "fuzzy math!"

You missed this line:

"A few states do bind their super delegates to the winner of the primary or caucus, but most do not."

So not all 50 states are contributing to this category of delegate.

There are 126 delegates, about 6 percent of the total, who are complete free agents. These are party leaders and elected officials, three per state or territory, ...

So we lost ten states somewhere along the line. You'd think that would have been in all the papers. 3 x 50 is at least 150, not 126.

Paul: I disagree. My personal belief is that States should have proportional representation of their primary/causus delegate votes. In a similar vein, the only change I would wish mandated regarding the Electoral College is for the votes to be required to be proportional to the popular vote of each State. That would require the candidates to work harder and achieve a more rounded representation. Consider how such debacles as the 2000 Florida vote would vanish under such an arrangement.

"Campaigning only allowed"...?

How would such a thing be enforced? What is "Campaigning?"

Say that your plan was in effect, and in the year 2019, Candidate John Smith holds a rally? Would he be punished? What if he writes a book? A newspaper article? Is interviewed on television? Because all of those things are in some ways "campaigning", in that they are attempts for a candidate to get publicity or support.

To say that campaigning would only be allowed in the election year is to say that you are going to suspend people's rights to free association, free assembly and free speech.

All one day? That means only the best-funded campaigns will have a chance. No candidate could build a case for him- or herself through speaking tours, debates, and so on.

Winner-take-all? Maybe, but why on the State level? Why not Congressional district? Or better still: Census tract?
This is why all states should have a winner take all primary on the same day (6 months before the general) with campaigning only allowed starting Jan 1 of the election year.

comments.parentUserDisplayName: King Krak, I Smell the Stench
comments.commentBody:
Because the best disinfectant for corruption is daylight.

If you show people just how Byzantine the primary process is, it will embarass the party into reforming it. If people don't realize that things need changing, nobody will demand change. If people read this article and come to their own independent conclusion that there's just too much red tape in the process, they'll be more likely to contact their local party organization and insist on reform.

comments.parentUserDisplayName: King Krak, I Smell the Stench
comments.commentBody: Because it's an entertaining freak show.

comments.parentUserDisplayName: King Krak, I Smell the Stench
comments.commentBody:
@Statler: This article makes me praise the process much more actually.

The only thing I wish we had is a book that laid out every state with all the rules in meticulous detail.

I hate reading things like "The rules for this state are complicated."

Yes, I know that. Tell me how.

comments.userDisplayName: King Krak, I Smell the Stench
comments.commentBody:
"The rules are so complicated and ambiguous that many delegates could go to the Republican convention either loosely pledged or entirely unbound to any of the candidates"

If this is the case, why give the Republican primary elections so much coverage?

Does he have 2 cadillacs?

If so, it's not a gaffe.

That's actually good news for Romney then.

I'm pretty sure Santorum can win California, but not sure if he can get to 50%.

Replying to mjcc1987. Your summary of voters is neither fair nor accurate. 70-80% of the voters know today, exactly how they're going to vote, either D or R (regardless of who's on the ballot), except that a certain percent of R voters may choose to not vote or vote for a 3rd party candidate as a protest. The remaining 20-30% are not idiots, but due to either lack of time, interest, understanding or culture, do not feel involved in the process or that their votes matter, or do not start to take an interest until just before the election. Many of them are in states where their votes really won't matter, either because the state votes overwhelmingly R or D. So elections come down to a fairly small percentage of voters in a few swing states.
But as to your conclusions, regardless of what the puppetmasters may think is best for the Republican Party, I find it utterly incredible that Romney, Santorum, Gingrich and Paul are actually conspiring to make sure the last man standing loses. There is far too much personal ego and animosity between them to coordinate something like that, and I can see no reason why Romney would spend 8 years of his life to intentionally lose two elections.
He and Newt can rule the moon together.

This man needs to find his own uninhabited island and reign there as king.  He's too dangerous to be entrusted with a vote let alone with an elected office..

Simple question, but maybe the answer is not so simple: What happens if a bound delegate votes for someone else? (The most likely scenario I could imagine would be a few delegates, realizing that Romney is going to just barely reach 1141, decide at the last minute that they would prefer a brokered outcome so they agree to vote for some other dude.)

Apple enjoys profit margins that are the envy of most other companies. Clearly this is due in part to using suppliers that are able to work their employees like slaves. Too bad Apple can't sacrifice a slice of their profits to enforce more humane working conditions.

Yes other companies also use Foxconn and yes, China is a developing country, etc. But these are basically other ways of saying "they can legally get away with it". Is that what we should be aiming for?

Everybody loves citing Steve Jobs success,... but I have yet to see him cited for the most important ability... I think... was the reason for his success.....The ability to learn from failure.

I think of more entrepreneurs focused on learning from their failures... we would have more successful entrepreneurs.

Great article. I teach entrepreneurs how to launch startups and find it interesting how there are those who get the business model and can take it and run with it, then there are those who get it but realize they need help achieving their goals.
Personally, I like what you mention about the best entrepreneurs are not necessarily the A students. I was always a good student, but bored to death in school and felt that there were bigger challenges out there waiting for me. Sounds like there are more out there like me.

Sustainability, the magic word. Mankind is living an unsustainable existence now. Fossil fuels while a bridge to energy that can be developed that is clean still pushes the enviornment & climate change further and faster with consequences we fail to realize. Developing economies are not going to slow down, the demands on supplies will grow, prices will rise and a tipping point will be reached where atmospheric forces change the face of earth as we know it today. Change of giant proportions can and have happened in decades in past history when these tipping points are reached. While those in past history were naturally induced, todays will be man made, and accelerated through the process of radical change in climate. Radical change is needed in how & what we use for energy and institue world wide Co2 emissions treaties, and start to take the issue seriously. Our failure to do so, puts us at our greatest peril.

FHS's comment meant to read that Ike led Britain, France, and Israel out of Egypt.  (Britain encouraged Ben Gurion to invade so that Britain and France would have a cover for intervening to depose Nasser.)

Great comment - lay America's current ills at the feet of a deadPresident who served 2 terms 50 years ago.

In addition to the other laudable accomplishments cited in other comments, remember that Ike sent federal troops to Little Rock (Arkansas) in '57 to support school integration, blocking Governor Faubus' attempts to prevent it.

Expecting Ike to address and fix the laundry list of issues in a post-war Amercia (WWII and Korea) is demeaning and diminishes his contributions to this country. This is a man who served as 1st Supreme Allied Commander in Europe. The sacrifices all Americans made during the war were not small, whether it was in lives, rationing, redirecting industrial output, etc.

Ike's service and memory does not deserve the acerbic burden of this comment.
G Lake: He was a brilliant general.  No argument there.  As a president- not so much.

Yeah, for the placid majority greatness seems to lie in the acceptance of the status quo. Among those problems that Ike declined to recognize and/or to address was the little issue of Jim Crow.  He allowed the disease of racism to fester and grow until, just a few short year later, it could no longer be contained.  Gays continued to hide in their closets and abortions were safe only for those who could afford to have their problems "taken care of" properly.  Women who wanted to work (or, worse yet, to have a job AND a family) were treated pretty much as they are now- in Pakistan.  During Ike's administration a legally elected Iranian president who wanted to nationalize his country's oil industry was deposed by the CIA (in concert with British intelligence) and replaced by the "bloodsucker of the century."  We've been paying for that brilliant decision for the past 40 years. The seeds of our Vietnam fiasco were, of course, also planted during Eisenhower's years in office.  It seems to me that there's already a perfect monument to Ike out in Anaheim.  It's a place called Disneyland, which was constructed while he was president and whose Main Street perfectly evokes the era that Mr. Douthat prefers to believe the rest of us lived through during Ike's presidency.

"On the Brink" Henry M. Paulson, Jr.
Pg 424. (First edition: February 2010: Hachette Group Book)

" For president Bush an auto bailout was a bitter pill to swallow, especially as the last major economic decision of his administration.He disliked bailouts, and he disdained Detroit for not making cars people wanted to buy. But we were in the midst of a financial crisis and a deepening recession, and he recognized that if the giant companies were to declare bankruptcy they would be doing so without advance planning or adequate financing for an orderly restructuring. The consequences for the economy would be devastating. It would create more panic, and it would crush the auto suppliers and other car makers -- not just Chrysler and Ford, but also Honda's and Toyota's U.S. operations. Although the president didn't explicitly say he would jump in to save the automakers, I knew he recognized --- once again -- the need for quick decisive action."

"Let's decentralize power when it comes to our electoral process, allowing local governments to experiment with Instant Runoff Voting (IRV) or None of the Above (NOTA)."

I agree with decentralizing power.

Boiling things down to the county level makes sense because then every district is important and the state doesn't get over-influenced by a city that represents 1% of the total area of the state.

But I'm not sure None of the Above makes sense.

If it won, where would the EV's and delegates go?

US: A Petroleum EXPORTING Country  (Not just, a Petroleum Producing country) !

The speculators are the ones who are largely responsible for driving gas prices.

Just think: Iran makes threatening noises (hasn't done anything significant yet) and the price of our gas produced long before the threatening noises) has gone up, and speculators had a long step ahead in making their profits at the expense of gas-using public not just in US but the world over. Nothing happened; just noises !!

Iran (Libya, Iraq or Venezuela) sneezes and we are down with pneumonia!

Also think: IF Iran did take actions (eg, blocked the strait of Hormuz, or stopped selling its own oil), would the gas prices rise astronomically higher? Perhaps. And the speculators win big, again.

Most speculators are US-based.

I see no good reason why we shouldn't join OPEC: we are after all a Petroleum Producing Country too (much like Saudi Arabia, Iran, Angola and Venezuela), and what stops US from joining that Organization of 12 member countries?
